question.para: Is the counterclockwise rotation of the plane about the origin through the angle \theta invertible?

info.para: Correct! – The inverse of R_{\theta} is R_{-\theta}; i.e. the rotation of \RNr[2] about the origin through the angle \theta in the clockwise direction.
Sorry! – No. The question here is if the transformation effect of R_{\theta} can be reversed. Why do you think this would not be the case?

question.para: Is the reflection of \RNr[3] about a hyperspace invertible?

answer.para: Yes! Such a reflection is invertible
No! Such a reflection is not invertible

question.para: Is the projection of \RNr[3] onto the xy-plane invertible?

info.para: Visualize the effect of this projection on an object: Shine a light vertically onto the object. Its shadow in the xy-plane is the outcome of the projection. Therefore the question is: can you always recover the original object from its shadow.

Sorry! No. – To see why such a projection is not invertible, consider the case where the projection of an object is a single point. In this case we do not know if the original is a single point or a vertical stick. Nor do we know how far either of these objects is from the xy-plane. Therefore such a projection is not invertible.

answer.para: No! This projection is not invertible.

info.para: Correct! – Why is it not invertible?

question.para: Is a shear transformation of \RNr[2] parallel to the x-axis invertible?

answer.para: Yes! Such a shear transformation is invertible.

info.para: Correct! – – Why is a shear transformation invertible? If the original shear transformation has shear vector \Vect{s}, then the shear transformation with shear vector -\Vect{s} will restore each point and each object in its original position.

answer.para: No! Such a transformation is not invertible.
